current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To authorize and request the President to award the Medal
		  of Honor posthumously to First Lieutenant Alonzo H. Cushing for acts of valor
		  during the Civil War.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced
			 the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

text.#text:
Alonzo H. Cushing
			 was born in Delafield, Wisconsin, on January 19, 1841.

Alonzo H. Cushing
			 graduated from the United States Military Academy at West Point, New York, on
			 June 24, 1861.

On July 3, 1863,
			 First Lieutenant Alonzo H. Cushing commanded Battery A, 4th United States
			 Artillery, Army of the Potomac, during the Battle of Gettysburg.

During the
			 battle, First Lieutenant Alonzo H. Cushing was shot multiple times but refused
			 to retreat.

First Lieutenant
			 Alonzo H. Cushing continued to command his battery until he was shot and
			 killed.

The Union victory
			 at the Battle of Gettysburg was one of the key turning points in the Civil
			 War.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: have determined that the actions of First Lieutenant Alonzo H. Cushing do merit the award of the Medal of Honor.

header.#text:
Authorization for
			 award of the Medal of Honor to First Lieutenant Alonzo H. Cushing for acts of
			 valor during the Civil War

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
,
			 or any other time limitation with respect to the awarding of certain medals to
			 persons who served in the Armed Forces, the President is authorized to award
			 the Medal of Honor under

to then First Lieutenant
			 Alonzo H. Cushing for conspicuous acts of gallantry and intrepidity at the risk
			 of life and beyond the call of duty in the Civil War, as described in

text.#text:
Notwithstanding
			 the time limitations specified in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
are the
			 actions of then First Lieutenant Alonzo H. Cushing while in command of Battery
			 A, 4th United States Artillery, Army of the Potomac, at Gettysburg,
			 Pennsylvania, on July 3, 1863, during the American Civil War.

text.#text: The acts of valor referred to in
